metadata.description: Comprehensive evaluation dataset for RAG system covering Tic-Tac-Toe and Chess rules
metadata.coverage: setup, gameplay, winning conditions, edge cases

queries.query: How many players can play Tic-Tac-Toe?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: Two players

queries.query: What size is the game board?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: 3x3 grid

queries.query: How do you win in Tic-Tac-Toe?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: Get three of your marks in a row (horizontal, vertical, or diagonal)

queries.query: Who goes first?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: Player X goes first

queries.query: Can you place your mark on an already occupied space?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: No, you cannot place a mark on an occupied space

queries.query: What happens if all spaces are filled and no one has three in a row?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: The game is a draw/tie

queries.query: How many different ways can you win?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: Eight ways: three rows, three columns, two diagonals

queries.query: Can you move a mark after placing it?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: No, once placed, marks cannot be moved

queries.query: How many pieces does each player start with?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: 16 pieces: 8 pawns, 2 rooks, 2 knights, 2 bishops, 1 queen, 1 king

queries.query: What is the size of a chess board?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: 8x8 squares, 64 squares total

queries.query: How does a pawn move?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: Moves forward one square, or two squares on first move. Captures diagonally forward one square.

queries.query: How does a knight move?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: Moves in an L-shape: two squares in one direction and one square perpendicular, can jump over pieces

queries.query: What is castling?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: A special move involving the king and rook where the king moves two squares toward a rook and the rook moves to the square the king crossed

queries.query: What is en passant?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: A special pawn capture that can occur when a pawn moves two squares forward from its starting position and lands beside an opponent's pawn

queries.query: How do you win at chess?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: Checkmate your opponent's king, or opponent resigns

queries.query: What is checkmate?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: When the king is in check and has no legal move to escape check

queries.query: What is stalemate?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: When a player has no legal moves but is not in check. The game ends in a draw.

queries.query: Can a pawn move backwards?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: No, pawns can only move forward

queries.query: What happens when a pawn reaches the opposite end of the board?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: The pawn is promoted to a queen, rook, bishop, or knight (player's choice, usually queen)

queries.query: Which piece can move in any direction any number of squares?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: The queen

queries.query: Can you castle if your king has already moved?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: No, castling is only legal if the king has not moved

queries.query: Can you castle while in check?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: No, you cannot castle while in check, through check, or into check

queries.query: What is the three-fold repetition rule?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: If the same position occurs three times with the same player to move, the game can be declared a draw

queries.query: What is the fifty-move rule?
queries.groundTruthAnswer: If fifty moves are made by each player without a pawn move or capture, the game can be declared a draw
